text:
Get Surly! Here’s what happens when substance meets smooth. This oatmeal brown ale defies traditional categories. Bender begins crisp and lightly hoppy, complemented by the velvety sleekness oats deliver. Belgian and British malts usher in cascades of cocoa, coffee, caramel, and hints of vanilla and cream. An easy-drinking ale with many layers of satisfaction.
Great tasting beer. Not too strong coffee taste. Dark in color. I would buy again 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Not my favorite. Has a stout taste with and ale finish. I would prefer this taste to be in a heavier stout or porter

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16floz pint. Dark-brown with good head retention. Lightly roasted aroma has a semblance to toffee. Feel is good and lightish, where the semi-sweet malt palate comes and goes quickly. Mild taste of caramel and hints of chocolate here and there make for a solid brew.
16oz can poursbrown color with a foamy beige head. aroma roasted malt and nuts flavor follows

Danish pint from an actual pint can; courtesy of Rob G. Aroma: Moderate malts that tend toward nuts, chocolate and a little toast; very light citrus hops. Appearance: Translucent chestnut brown beer with a sticky tan head that settles into a thin ring. Flavor: Aforementioned malts and citrus hops at about a 60/40 split; citrus lingers lightly afterwards; the finish is semi-dry and lightly bitter. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: A pretty nice brown ale that manages to exceed most of its peers.
Pours a light brown color with a foamy off white head. Notes of roasted nuts, milk chocolate, and vanilla. Nice but feels a bit thin.

A perfect brown. The only thing stopping a perfect score is aroma and palate complexity but in some ways the straightforward palate is in itself part of what makes this a straight fastball brown. Very impressive!

On tap at Village Green.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the tap, at Zelo, Minneapolis. Pours dark brown with beautiful ruby reflections and fine brownish foam. Aroma is not intense, with just some maltiness and terrain. Body is medium with some level of carbonation. Taste is moderate sweetness and bitterness, with oatmeal emerging in the finish.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Pint can. Caramel malt aroma with notes of cocoa, coffee, vanilla and a hint of hops. Pours dark brown colored with one finger of light brown head that has excellent retention but no lacing. Starts with rich cocoa and caramel malt flavors to go along with the rich, full body. Finishes lightly dry but smooth with vanilla, light hops and, most notably, coffee that lingers on the palate. Very good brown ale.

Can, the pour is dark auburn with strong red heels, and the head is thick and tan and color. The aroma has hops some sort of spiced notes to it. The taste is crisp, slight coffee, and solid roasted flavors buy a clean crisp finish.

Can.

A- Oak, subtle booze, fruit esters, chocolate.

A- Brown mahogany color, clear liquid, tan head.

T- Caramel, malty, subtle fruits.

P- Medium body, slightly thin texture, average carbonation, complex finish

O- Easily one of the best brown ales Ive had. Didnt get any coffee, vanilla, or anything really that I expected. Instead it smelled and tasted like a lighter bodied scotch ale. Quite frankly, I dont care as it was tasty.

Can thanks to trade with HuskerTan! Pours a slightly hazy deep brown with thin wispy tan head. Aroma of dark roast coffee and a hint of clean fruity esters. Taste follows, mild and clean. Decent brown ale, but not sure the hype is there.

Dark, toasted malts, light chocolate, some coffee. Hazy, dark brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. Bitterness intensifies, more dark, toasted malts, cereals, coffee, light cacao, medium carbonation, medium bodied. Nice Brown Ale, well-balanced. Keg at the brewery, Minneapolis.
On tap at the brewery. Brown pour with a kaki head. Malty aromas. Caramel malts, toffee, and hints of orange peel. Good body and mouthfeel. Smooth.
Not a whole lot too this. Light roast and lots of mash malt. Might be better fresh, but not a top brown ale for me. Dark mahogany pour. Tangy mash finish. Tap at Churchkey.

Merci à Stéphane pour cette canette pour le moins... étonnante. Liquide brun foncé et translucide. Des arômes de sucre dorge, de cerises au marasquin, de malts sucrés et sans subtilité. Peu ou pas de goût. Un peu de café peut-être et damertume qui provient don ne sait où. Pas de houblons, ni de torréfaction. Une amertume cheap. Finale mince de vieilles chaussettes. Moche moche moche.
Wow. This is much better for mine than the coffee version. Big, tawny body, lots of caramel and dark mats, almost stout like.Drinks much bigger than 5 %. World class.
Sample from can. Pours dark brown, tan head. Aroma was malty, hazelnuts and vanilla. Taste was sweet and malty.

Lata de 480 ml conseguida en Ultramarinos Franco, Ciudad de México. Aroma a nueces, vainilla, ciruelas, caramelo. Notas a caramelo, cacao, vainilla, tal vez un poco de canela. Perfectamente balanceada y facil de beber en cualquier ocasión. Mis respetos para Surly Brewing Co!
pour red brown with a light tan head. cocoa, and light caramel aroma, Taste light sweet with bitter notes. medium bodied, average carbonation.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar Aarhus. Pours reddish brown with a medium offwhite head.
Aromas of malt, chocolate, light hoppiness, orange sweetness.
Taste is malty, chocolate, bitter, toasty, sweet.
Tap @ Mikkeller bar, Aarhus. Clear brownish pour with a a fluffy head. Notes of caramel, malty sweet, light hops, syrup, grains and a light bitter finish.
From tap at Mikkeller & Friends. Fark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, roasted, nuts, hops and bitterness.

Toasty and roasty aroma and taste, treacle, caramel and toffeish sweetness, some nutty notes, brown sugar, sweet malty finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can. Clear deep brown pour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet malty caramel, hint of nuts. Taste is a little sweet and lightly roasty, some caramel and nutty notes, a touch of dark fruits. Simple but quite nice.
Clear dark brown pour with a medium sized beige head. Nutty caramel aroma. Taste follows but is a little thin. Light body.
Pours lightly hazy to a deep reddish brown hue. dark beige head with lots of lacing. caramel, brown sugar, nuts, chocolate, vanilla, ready aroma. super smooth. loved it.
Nice solid brown. Big vanilla and cocoa taste. Full malty taste. Perfect balanced medium body.

16 ounce can into pint glass, canned on 7/24/2015. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy deep reddish brown color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted oats, nuttiness, chocolate, cocoa, light coffee/vanilla, herbal, floral, and roast/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted oats, nuttiness, chocolate, cocoa, light coffee/vanilla, herbal, floral, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light herbal/spicy hop and roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted oats, nuttiness, herbal, floral, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with a great bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky, and slightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish as expected of 5.1%. Overall this is an excellent American brown ale. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Can. Pours dark red-brown with thick tan head and substantial lacing. Subtle chocolate aroma with coffee, vanilla, and cream notes. Bitterness upfront followed by roasted malt, slight chocolate and coffee. Vanilla and roasted malt with a touch of smoke in the long finish. Silky mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16 oz can. Canned on 07/24/15. Thanks a lot Timo A!
Clear dark red color with a tiny light tan head.
The aroma is dry hops, mild bitterness, dryness, berries and malt.
The flavor is dry hops, berry hops, some sweetness and dry maltiness. More Red Ale than Brown Ale to me. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wasn't sure what to expect but pleasantly surprised. Not much aroma but it might have been that I didn't let it warm up. Mouthfeel good. Taste yum.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
nice super hoppy brown ale. has a nice nutty hoppy finish with some roasted malt notes. smells nutty and hoppy. pours almost black with a really thick lacey brown head. had out of a can at home.

Pours dark brown with a huge tan head. Aroma is thick with dark roasty bread and toddy notes. Body is medium to heavy. Flavour is malty and rich. Finish is thick as well and only slightly sweet, with a drying feeling.
A can in Minnesota airport Good tan head and lace, thick dark brown pour, aroma of chocolate and roasted malt, good thick malty body with plenty off roasted malt and chocolate,

Can at home picked up in Minnesota. Pour is deep brown with a small tan head and sticky lacing. Cookie malt, brown sugar, sweet dough, some pepper, and light earthiness in the aroma. Taste is brown malty, roasty, toasted bread, light cocoa, grass, and brown sugar with a slightly bitter finish. Light body with high carbonation. Pretty good - very hoppy for the style - would benefit greatly from a thicker body.

Can. Pours cola brown with light beige head. Aroma is chocolate, oats, light roasted malts, faint prune, faint tobacco, and faint lactose. Flavor is dry and a little ashy with good chocolate notes, soft sweetness, and a good creamy finish. Medium body.
Can at home. Deep brown pour. Nose is cocoa and cookies. Tastes of chocolate chip cookies, caramel, plum, roasted malt, some resin, cocoa, and coffee. Fine smooth palate slight bite. Quite nice.

On tap at Ikes in the Minneapolis/St. Paul airport. Fantastic head, thick and sulfur in queue, capping a stunning, nutmeg-brown liquid. The aroma is amazing, caramel, vanilla, some Belgian dough, which is quickly becoming one of my favorite accents to a beer. The taste is a lightly sweetened umami, savory with a bit of dessert accent; The flavor mirroring the aroma almost exactly and delivering delicious layers of experience. The medium body is a perfect, and the carbonation is spot on. I would definitely buy this again!
Dark, dark brown pour. Big tan head. Plenty of lacing. Huge malty aroma. Big malty flavor. Sweet malty finish.

16 oz can from Hy-Vee Wine & Spirits into a pint glass. Dark brown and pretty clear appearance with a light brown head and light lacing. Aroma and flavor of toffee, vanilla, dark fruits, cocoa, caramel, earthy hops and dark malts. Similar flavor, moderately sweet with a mild bitter finish. Medium body. The coffee version is much better.
16oz can pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Rich maltiness, mild hops. A little too sweet for me.

Pours very dark amber with tan head. Aroma is mostly english malts, not getting much else. Light body, with a crisp citrus hoppyness. little bit of toffee on the malt side, some caramel. Vanilla and coffee. Pretty good.
earth wood cherries pine,malty a touch sweet. Awesome. Totally amazing example of the style.

Cola like appearance. Great lacing. Smell that British toast and delicate malt, cocoa and vanilla. Smells as taste. Lots of vanilla on the front. Softer coffee in the back. Could use more coffee 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown pour with a two finger, creamy tan head that has great retention and leaves decent lacing. Aroma is toast, chocolate, nutty notes, brown malt, toasted granola, caramel. Flavor is nutty malt and cereal up front, sweet chocolate, a hint of light roast coffee, a little earthy, toasty wood, herbal, light citrus and pine hops. Medium body, creamy feel on entry light to medium, blanketing carbonation and a slightly drier finish with a hint of tannin astringency. Really good, great flavor and body for 5.1%.

Dark plummy black but clear red hue. Aroma has some bread/toast toffee, light sweet, plummy raison, slight chocolate, light citrus, berry, nuts,somewhat mild aroma overall,yet complex. This is crisp,light, soft, light chocolate, light nutty,more berry in flavor than anything else, citrus is stronger in finish. tangy finish. Curious of the coffee bender, this one seems pretty acidic to go with coffee. think this wouldnt go good as it doesnt seem rich enough to support coffee. It must cuz it has a slight better rating than this.
Canned 12/30/2014. Smooth and drinkable brown ale. Not a heavy chocolate taste but very tasty foe a brown ale. Smells like caramel.
16 oz can pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of malts, caramel and chocolate. Taste is sweet malts and some chocolate.
Flight at MSP. Sweet, smooth brown ale. Sweet malt nose, some chocolate comes on at the tail end. A bit on the sweet side, but very tasty.
Dark brown with a fluffy cream colored two finger head. Nice clean smell of vanilla, oats, roasted barley. Like the can says hops up front a creamy oatmeal in the middle and finish.
16oz bottle. Dark brown with an average beige head. Aroma is of roasted malts, toasted nuts, cocoa, earth. Taste is of roasted malts, pecan shells, bark, earth, and toast.
Can. The look is brown in color, beige colored head, and dark. The smell is dirty, nuts, shells, pencil shavings, hops, hazelnuts, and roasty. The taste is sweet, roast, malt, hops, and ok.

Oatmeal aroma. Nice fluffy brown head. Dark brown appearance, looks thinner than a stout but thicker than an ale. Very nice coffee and oatmeal on the front with some vanilla on the aftertaste. Really nice.

Really muddy dark brown pour with a thin haze of oatmeal fizz on top. Aroma of toffee, maybe cinnamon? sweeter chocolate and cream, herbal presence too. Lively carbonation for the style, thicker almost sticky mouthfeel, finishes clean. Fairly straightforward mellow oat flavor accompanied by some mesquite wood, Mexican chocolate, toffee, strong acidic coffee, possibly some cinnamon. Pretty unique oatmeal stout.
Can. Pours clear super dark ruby with very thin off white head. Nose is chocolate, some roast and dark fruit. Taste is chocolate and caramel. Good.

16oz can, not poured. For the appearance, Im going to give it an average rating based on other reviews. The aromas are mild with notes of oats, herbs, caramel, a bit of ash, and some chocolate. Its medium sweet and bitter, with perhaps a touch more bitterness. Its smooth with a fuzzy and lightly fizzy carbonation. The medium-light body is roasty with herbal notes, chocolate, coffee, molasses, and secondary touches of vanilla, and cream (and perhaps even some coconut). The finish is ash and herbs and the ash lingers with coffee and a slight tobacco.

16 oz can at Newts in Rochester, Minnesota, served in a pint glass. Pours clear reddish brown with a large tan head that fades slowly to a thin cover and leaves lots of fine lace. The nose has lots of herbal hops, bready malts, oatmeal and earth along with a mild resinous hoppy note. The flavour is mildly sweet throughout with brown sugar and nutty, bready malts; this is paired up with a slight resinous hoppy note. Notes of chocolate, vanilla, toasted malts and perhaps coconut come through as well. The finish is long and balanced, with vanilla, cocoa, resin and pine. On the palate it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture. Overall, a decent nut brown ale-meets-oatmeal stout. 2014-12-15
Can pours a dark brown with Amber highlights and a large khaki head. Aroma of molasses, caramel, and cocoa. Taste similar to aroma with some dry bitter hops and a smooth palate. A nice brown.

Sampled from a 16oz can this beer poured a dark brown color with a large creamy orange-brown head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was somewhat bitter with floral hops, sour dark fruits and toffee. The flavor was tangy and sour with malt, oatmeal, coffee, cocoa, vanilla, nut and a bit of sour dark fruits. Long finish. Moderately full bodied and creamy. Interesting.
Can thanks to Will. Very dark brown. Medium beige head. Roasted. A little bit of wood in there. Nice bitter roastiness but not smooth like coffee.
Can at Mikkeller Stockholm. Brown pour with very small head. Nutty aroma and taste with some caramel, light coffee and chocolate. Light and tasty.

Julie think its a smooth light hoppy brown sle.  Julie gives a 3.8

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Olmost black with a brown head - Good malt aroma - Good malt body with some roasted malt, caramel and chcoloate, with some bitterness - Roasted malt goes into the finish - This was good

Surly Bender has a thick, beige, crackling, foam head, a clear, somewhat bubbly, brown appearance, and substantial lacing left on the glass. Aroma is of rich, sweet, malty, brown bread, and the flavor is of the same elements, with wonderful, non-fruity and non-piney, straightforward bitterness. The oats also shine through, as one sips it down. Mouthfeel is medium and a bit velvety. Surly Bender finishes semi-wet and easy drinking. RJT

"an oatmeal brown ale. hmmm. not bad. perhaps i was expecting greatness from all things Surly and this one is only good? An above average, flavorful, roasted brown ale. a little thin on the body but smooth, and, well, most browns are a touch thin, and this one is better than many."

Can at a BOSS meeting thanks to Brent. Pours very dark brown. Nice head. Some roast and chocolate. Nice mouthfeel. Nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from De Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Dark red-brown, clear body, with a big, creamy, brown head. Aroma of chocolate, nuts, earth, dark berries, some roast. Tastes of coffee, chocolate, nuts, wood, earth, berries, some citric hops. Mouthfeel is light, slick, with a moderate carbonation and it finishes medium bitter-roasty, also with dark chocolate and some fruity notes. Nice! Quaffable, well balanced between sweet and roasty and with interesting earthy notes. Pretty light mouthfeel, but thats typical of this style. Overall a great, far beyond average Brown Ale!

Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma has that sweet malty notes up front along with some nuts, toffee and some weak roasted notes. Also some weak hope notes and sweeter fruits as well. Taste is sweet, yet roasty and bitter. Some coffee is detectable here as well as caramel, sweeter fruits and hops. Nice interpretation of the IMO boring style.
Draft. Dark brown with medium tan head. Aroma toffee, caramel, and malt. Medium body, toffee, caramel, toasted malt, some molasses, and a dry finish.

Can. Dark brown nearly black body with tan head. Aroma is malts with some caramel and hints of coffee. Taste is lightly roasted malts with coffee and caramel. Aftertaste is very smooth with medium bitterness and loads of caramel and coffee. Nice one.

Canned from Mikkeller&Friends
Dark brown with a tan head. 
Chocolate and dark toffee in the aroma. 
Toffee in the flavour along with tidbits and some peaty, tar-notes. 
Light bitterness and fresh palate.

@ Nedre Mölla 9/7-14. Can from Mikkeller & Friends Bottle Shop. Aroma: Hoppy, caramel, licorice, chocolate. Taste: Chocolate, notes of nuts and caramel. Body is medium, the finish is medium bitter with notes of chocolate and hops.

Mahogany brown in color... Aroma of oats, roasted malts, nuts... Flavor is fairly nutty, nice oatmeal smooth mouthfeel, lots of nuts on the finish... Decent

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy brown with some ruby highlights. Some floaters and some chunks on the bottom of the glass. Thin off-white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Thin watery mouth-feel. A strange tartness in the beginning followed by a mellow caramel flavor.

Medium-brown in color with orange hues, this looks like a light-bodied, wet brown ale. The nose is powerful, fruity, slightly sour, malty, and distinctive. As clean and wet as it looks its soft and almost chewy in the mouth and it reminds me a little of an oatmeal cookie. Its very English, but refreshing and makes for a nice English-style summer session ale. A dry character finishes the beer, but its still clean and delicious.

16fl oz can. Pours a clear, deep ruby/caramel with a one finger, tan head that laces. Aroma has notes of caramel, dark fruits, smooth roasted malts, and some fruity esters. Taste is balanced. Again, fruity English yeast taste with smooth caramel blended with mild roasted malts. Mild aftertaste. Low-medium body with a medium carbonation. Smooth in the mouth. Very drinkable. Overall a really nice brown. Super drinkable with smooth flavours of mild roasted malts, caramel, and fruity, English ale yeast. Yum.
Poured dark reddish brown with a beige froth. Aroma of sweet roast malt, dark chocolate, coffee, mocha. Medium body, very smooth, flavour as the aroma.

16oz can, canned 5/02/14. Thanks to Scott L. for sharing. Brown color, with a good thin khaki head, that leaves good thicker lace. Good chocolate, nutty notes. Light to medium body. Awesome full mouthfeel, nice creamy texture to it. Definitely smooth. Get some of that oatmeal, works great. Hints of dark fruit. Light dry finish. Moderate bitter taste, light to moderate sweet. Fantastic brown ale. Super smooth and easy drinking, yet such awesome full flavor. Would be a great one to enjoy with some food, I imagine.

Can:
Pours hazy red-brown with a tall, thick, tan head.
Earthy nut, chocolate aroma.
Taste is roast coffee, nuts, chocolate malt.
Nice coffee/earthy bittering.
Very malty and creamy.
Really great.

Can from Mikkeller online shop; dark brown pour with a big frothy beige head, caramel and wood aroma, taste has resinous pine, caramel, roast coffee, slight bitterness, a hint of spice, creamy mouthfeel.
Excellent beer for all seasons. Smooth brown ale. Great smell and brown/amber color. Malty and rich. One of my favorite browns.
Pours a nice brown color with tan head. Coffee, oats, cocoa, vanilla, spice, and a little pine on the nose; follows onto the palate. Very complex for a brown ale. Finishes with malt.
Can. Light woody coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown with nice head. Sweet woody coffee and chocolate malt and bitter herbal flavor. Decent body.
47 cl can @ home. Pours brown with a little sediment and an off-white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma and flavour are roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and nuts - with a slightly bitter finish.

On tap at POPE by accident (bartender gave me the wrong Bender). Aroma of malt malty malt, some nut, bread, and chocolate. Pours nut brown and hazy with a small fluffy head. Taste was nice and malty with chocolate, malt, and slight bread crust. Warm thick mouthfeel but it goes down like butter. This is an amazingly perfect brown ale. I was impressed.
Un corps svelte peuplé de malts rôtis et chocolatés qui se laissent dominer par un tranchant lactique en finale.

Draught @ Haand Ølfestival 2014
Pours clear brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, malt dust, hint of chocolate and floral hops. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.
Can from a bottle shop in Copenhagen (probably Mikkeller & friends). Hoppy malty with caramel and dark bread. Similar taste. Nice hoppy brown ale although i recon the hop is a bit subdued now.

[Can] Deep brown color with a small cap of beige head. Nose is of cocoa powder, caramel and a light nuttiness. Flavors include milk chocolate, burnt caramel, vanilla, light coffee and a good malty backbone. Creamy palate. Low carbonation levels. Clean and tasty. Tasting notes from early 2012.
Sample at Haand. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is full bodied, roasty with some coffee.

Tap at Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen. Dark reddish brown shade with a ring of head. First thing I pick up is the hops. Kind of earthy, spicy and fruity, maybe English hops? Malt backbone is a little smoky. Clearly a fruity red grape-like influence too. Very different to what I expected, but nice once I got used to it.
Can, pours a nice brown with beige head, sweet taste of roasted malt, caramel, and hints of chocolate and vanilla, light bitter finish, good brown ale

On tap at Mikkeller & Friends. 

Dark brown with a small head. On the sweet side with malt, chocolate, toffee and some dried fruit. Quite soft and easy to drink.

On tap at Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen. Ruby brown with a tan head. Aroma is hazelnut, chocolate, caramel. Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel, well balanced on the palate. Taste is caramel, hazelnut, chocolate, malt.

Draught @ Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen

Pours reddish with a small white head. Aroma of vegetables, berries, cold coffee, mild roastiness and syrup. Taste is smooth, syrupy and mildly roasty with some cold coffee, chocolate and syrup. Finish is sweetish and a bit stuffy with some cold coffee and syrup. A bit unbalanced and feels a bit off.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a dark brown colour with an amber hue. Aroma of red berries, fruit cake and some grass. Flavour of toasted malts, some berries, grass and dried apricot. Medium bodied and a dry, malty, bready finish. Feelds old.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2014 Draught @ Mikkeller & Friends
Aroma has berries, strong malty tones and hints of cocoa. Flavour has berries, malt, some toffee and hints of minerals. Not sure about the style but this feels like doppelbock.

Tap @ Mikkeller & Friends.
Pours dark ruby red color with a small head. Malty and coffee-infused aroma with fruits and caramel. Flavor is pretty much the same with cocoa and vanilla notes. Nice and simple.
4325

Can poured into pint glass. Deep brown pour with a tanned head and nice mild carbonation. Sits nicely in between a porter and brown ale style. Heavily roasted with chocolate malts right upfront in the palate. Medium mouthfeel with a slight sweet note that breaks this ahead of similar ales - perfect for a chilled Spring evening.

Dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, cocoa, coffee, & some nuts; Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, hops, coffee, some caramel, and nuts; Dry finish; Pretty decent.

Can. Deep brown liquid with medium light tan head. Aroma of bread, chocolate, dried fruit, caramel, toffee and light fruity hops. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of chocolate, dried fruit, bread and toffee. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice.
Extra from bobbyD. Has a sweet malty woody taste and aroma. Average craft brown taste.

On tap at Ikes at MSP. Pours brown with a reddish tint; tan foamy head with nice lacing. Aroma is somewhat subdued, but toasted malt, caramel, and lactose hit the nose. Taste follows suit finishing with a mildly bitter dry finish. Body seems a bit on the light side to me. Crisp carbonation. Good brown ale.

Can. Deep mahogany. Oaky nose, with caramel and light vanilla; dark spices and sweet resiny pine. Caramel up front in the taste, crunchy almost nutty maltiness. Vanilla and light oak add to the sweetness. Depth of flavour comes with a big piney hit and dark fruit character. Medium body. Lingering caramel, fruit and pine. Great stuff

Can, shared at my 5K tasting. It pours deep brown with a small beige head. The nose is toasty, coffee, woody, caramel, cocoa and dark fruits. The taste is toast, wood, caramel, earth, raisin, varnish, brown bread, coffee, toffee and some dark fruit/berry with a dry finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. A solid, rather drinkable brown ale by all accords.

Can (canned 12/30/13) poured into a nonic pint glass. Pours dark brown almost black with just over a finger of light tan head, good lacing. Much better head and lacing than Coffee Bender. Aromas of caramel, toffee, sweet malt, light vanilla. Tasting notes of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, some dark fruit, bits of milk chocolate, subtle coffee, light piney hops. Creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Medium body with a semi-dry finish. Pretty nice, definitely can tell the differences between this and Coffee Bender.
Deep brown body topped by foamy khaki head. Amazing lace. Oats, roasted malt, coffee nose. Coffee, caramel, creamy flavors with a hint of vanilla and cocoa. Velvety smooth.
16oz can pours a dark cola brown with a small head and little lacing. Aromas of toasted malt, caramel, chocolate, and leather. Slightly bitter malt flavor with a nice finish.

Bottle shared at Scopeys 5000th rate. Cheers to Leighton I think. Pours dark brown with a dense beige head. Nose is full of heavily roasted coffee beans, melted caramel and some mild aniseed. Taste is more or less the same but has some more balance to the coffee notes. Drinks well with fine carbonation and a mild bitter finish. Solid drop
Tasty oatmeal brown ale...pours dark brown to black...minimal head...tastes of vanilla oatmeal caramel.....some lacing.....very tasty beer.
Great British style brown ale. Coffee, oatmeal, and earthy scent. Beautiful color.

Very smooth and drinkable. Kind of a mix of a stout, porter and ale. Dark roasted malts with a nice hop bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

One of the best brown ales Ive ever enjoyed. Its more complex and flavorful than many that Ive had. Its very sweet but it also has a bit of spice. This is one of those beers that unveils something new in each sip. Consequently, its also one of those beers that disappears way too quickly.

From notes.  First reviewed 2/22/2011.  Poured from a 16 oz. can into a pint glass.

The pour is easy out of the wide mouth can. A full walnut brown color with a generous ruby tint around the borders of the glass. A frothy tan head forms initially, retains well, and leaves a web of lace down the side of the glass.

A lot of nice aromas here. The hazelnut is most dominant, but there is a burnt brown sugar aroma adding some sweetness, and a robust earthy hop aroma to bring a nice balance to it all. 

Toasted dark malt, caramel, burnt brown sugar and hazelnut are all present in the taste up front. The taste turns a little bitter, with a nice woody and earthy hop presence. There is a growing bitterness with each sip, but it never gets in the way of the other flavors.

This has a mostly smooth mouthfeel, with a light graininess throughout each sip. Medium carbonation and a medium body. 

There is a good level of complexity here that makes this an exceptionally drinkable brown.

Brown body hosts a thick foamy light tan head with nice staying power. Nose is full of spicey zest and yeasty malt. Enters the mouth with a nice mingling of hops and rich roasted oats. Slightly burnt malt gives almost a coffee like after taste. Hops have a little bite on the end of the palate. This is a unique brew that I could drink everyday.

Hops are a little more pronounced as it warms and the beer leaves a dry, slightly metallic finish with a faint hint of pepper and raisin.

Overall I do enjoy this beer (second time having it) but Im more eager to try Coffee Bender. Maduro is one of my go-to beers here in FL and like I said, this reminds me of it, but I dont know if Id drink it as often were I living in MN.

I received a 16oz can in a donation from a fan in Minnesota (thanks, Sean!). I poured it into Geordie Schooner glass.

Appearance: Dark brown color, completely opaque but with a lot of carbonation bubbles sticking to the glass. Forms a dark khaki, creamy head which retains and laces very well.

Smell: Slightly confectionary notes of the typical brown ale variety (caramel, toasted malt) with distinct flowery hop fragrance as well.

Taste: Where the line is drawn between a very hoppy brown ale and a Brown IPA proper is for the beer nerds of the world to decide and I think Surly Bender would be the apex of that argument. Really, this beer could go either way. It has a nice floral character and dry hoppy bitterness that complements the traditional brown ale qualities.

I was surprised when the first thing I noticed about the first sip was an overt, sharp bitterness. Its crisp, a tad fizzy, and a molecule or two of pine is detectable as well. The palate turns on a dime into a brown ale with some stout or porter-like qualities. Bakers chocolate, light caramel and nuttiness impart a sweet (but not cloying) balance to the palate. It finishes with toasted malts and returns to the original hop bitterness it started out with. Its really impressive how these flavors can work so well together. 

My only complaint would be that the hops seems to outshine the brown ale qualities. Surly Bender, in my opinion, might be more accurately classified as a brown IPA than a brown ale. The candy bar-like taste of the second half fades away a little too quickly. Still, the palate remains very satisfying until the end.

Mouthfeel: Perfectly medium-bodied with noticeable carbonation fizz. Hops linger for a moment or so, but is otherwise a clean aftertaste.

Drinkability: Im shocked that Surly Bender is only 5.1% ABV as it has the sheer energy and weight of a stronger brew. Not that one drink will fill you up or gets you drunk, just that its amazing its able to do so much on a lighter scale. Not sure if I would session this as the hops would become annoying, but itd be a great choice to have with a hearty meal.

Poured into a pint glass. Big thanks to nickd717 for this extra.

4.0 A: Clear medium orange color. Two fingers of frothy light brown head with average retention and moderate lacing.

4.0 S: Roastiness with a pleasant nuttiness to it. A touch of cacao powder to boot. Nice but not strong enough.

4.5 T: Really tasty. Everything I want in a brown. Subtle roastiness and lots of nuttiness again. Medium bitterness.

4.5 M: Rich, creamy medium body. Good carbonation. Very smooth. Well done.

4.5 D: Damn tasty brown. Couldnt ask for much more.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 12-23-2009 03:44:32
Poured from a 16oz can.  Pours brown with some tan head.  Smells of caramel and coffee.   Taste is toffee and much more hoppiness than I would have imagined for this.  Easy drinking beer for sure.

Pours very dark red, with one finger off-white head. Aroma is of sweet malts toffee, caramel, biscuits, dark fruit, chocolate. Taste brings out the dark fruits even further; very sweet, with a bit of balance from spruce/grapefruit hops. Thin mouthfeel, moderate carbonation; velvety, creamy texture.
Poors brown with a tan head.  Malty on the nose.  Hops are under contol with tastes of caramel, cocoa, and a little bit of coffee.

Tasted on 12/31/10 from a 16oz can purchased at Discount Liquor, no discernible date on the can.  Pours cloudy dark brown with an average off-white head that leaves fairly thick spotty lace.  The nose is caramel malt with some nutty and roasted characteristics.  The flavor is sweeter malts up front, with chocolate and a very pleasant roasted note with bitter cocoa and coffee on the back.  The body is light with average carbonation and a long roasted coffee and cocoa finish.

A deep brown pour with ruby highlights and a tan head.  It has a light caramel and chocolate aroma mixed with some floral hops.  The medium body begins mildly sweet with a sticky texture.  It bitters up in the middle before a lightly roasted finish.

From notes:

Pours a very dark ruby red/chestnut brown color with deep mahogany edges when held to a light source and a thin foamy tan head that quickly fades into a thing lasting ring. Minimal spots of lacing left behind.

The aroma is slightly bland and for me the least impressive characteristic of this beer. Plenty of malt in the nose with hints of oatmeal, chocolate, toffee and caramel.

Surprisingly hop forward that adds some crisp bitterness up feot balancing out by the mellow chocolate malt center. Slightly roasty with hints of bread, toffee and nut as well as a slight lactic creaminess. The bitterness lingers throughout into a roasty dry finish but this beer is very well balanced and easy to drink.

Can to glass.  A decent Surly offering.  Pours a nice clear brown with red highlights.  Great lacing.  Aroma is all about malt, maybe a touch a dark fruit.  Taste is much the same.  Toasty malt notes, some oaken tones,  maybe a touch of vanilla.  Nice lingering bitterness.

Reddish brown with a thick, foamy faded white head. Dark brown malt aroma. Oatmeal, and creamy brown barley malt flavor. The oatmeal is really strong and the dominant flavor. A full malty aftertaste lingers for a lomg time.
can thanks to tyto. a damn good brown ale. nice and malty, not too heavy, but a great mouthfeel for what it is.

A: Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan had and plenty of lacing.

S: Lots of hops for a brown ale, and they really fit in well. Sweet caramel, toffee, and other roasted malts fill this one out.

T: Caramel, toffee, citrus/pine hops. Also some mild notes of coffee and chocolate.

M: Very rich and tasty. Medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation.

D: Highly drinkable. A very nice offering--I wouldnt expect anything less from Surly.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head, good lacing.  Nose of bread and yeast.  Taste is similar to the smell, sweet, with a hint of spice.  More character than other brown ales, but still fairly bland in my opinion.

16oz can courtesy of beeranddogs. Pour is muddy brown with a rocky, fluffy, tan head that sticks around leaving excellent poofy lace along the sides of the glass. Aroma is fresh, floral, light peppermint, mint chocolate chip. Taste is cola, sweet, roasty, bitter chocolate. Soft, bubbly palate. Really just a solid session beer. A good brown ale is a difficult thing to find.

On tap in Minneapolis.  Comes a clear reddish brown witha nice biege head.  Aroma of caramel malt, chocolate, coffee, citrus and hops.  Tastes is complex with the malt, chocolate and caramel coming to the front with the hops emerging at the finish.  Excellent.

Ill say Im not a fan of this style, but this is a decent beer. Pours a bit transparent brown, great aroma, and a great flavor to put down. I enjoy their staple Furious more. Even more so their Wet and Darkness which are both phenomenal.

Nice brown color, big head. Lots of lace. Hoppy nose. Lightly roasty/toasty malt flavor. Well balanced w/ interesting interaction between malt and hops. Very highly drinkable and very nicely flavorful. Really good brown ale.

The first brown ale I have really loved. Bender does what it says and delivers a flavor that covers all bases with amazingly smooth transition.

Very happy with this year round offering from Surly, which is easily becoming my favorite brewer and I havent even cracked my 2010 darkness!

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 I think I had this at Kumas. Anyway, very good beer. However it took me a few sips to get what it was all about. It starts kind of all over the place but then as your mouth gets used it, it really works. Serving: Tap
Brew courtesy of dalzale, thanks greg.  Ive been waiting to try this for sometime now and it doesnt disappoint.  This is one of the best browns ive had.  I look forward to future surly beers.

Tap at a few places in Minneapolis. Pours a somewhat clear, brown colored body with a finger-width, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is some nice brown maltiness with lots of rich caramels and chocolates, a good amount of earth, and a light roast. Some cocoa powder, a very light coffee, nuts, vanilla, and brown sugar. Flavor is similar. Very nice array of caramels, chocolates, toffees, brown sugar, and roasts. Some more cocoa powder, earth, nuts, oatmeal cookies, and coffee. Ends smooth and dry with a rich and malty, roasty, earthy, somewhat bitter finish that leaves a lengthy aftertaste. Very smooth, medium body and a moderate, creamy carbonation. Overall, a very nice brown ale. Extremely easy drinking and flavorful with a solid balance. A pleasure.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2010 I tried this beer at the Minneapolis airport. Very nice thick head that lasted for awhile. The aroma was  roasted malt with chocolate undertones. Nice hop infused rich carmel and chocolate flavor. I would recommend this to anyone. I wish I could find this in Colorado.
Shockingly complex beer from a can...sampled this hoppy offering in late summer.  Slight coffee taste but not as strong a coffee bender.  Some hop after taste.
Can, thanks to t0rin0 (I think). Pours with a brown body and a tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, chocolate, and grain. Taste is brown sugar, molasses, grain, and coffee. Dry mouthfeel, solid brown.

A: snifter. pours a nice rich brown, like black coffee. light tan head. great retention rate and wonderful lacing.

S: wonderful roasted malts, caramel, toffee, some vanilla, ans sweet wild flowers.

T: wow this is really complex. tons of chamomile, tea flavors, oats, light vanilla, coffee, caramel, and tons of oatmeal. light flowery hops. huge vanilla in the finish.

M: very chewy. extremely smooth and crisp. perfect carbonation level. buttery.

D: what a great brown ale. so unique, great flavors and definitely worth a try. absolutely delicious.

Courtesy of Ryan. Brown, minimal beige head, fades to ring. Huge caramel/crystal aroma up front, faint chocolate, hops seem a little old. Flavor much the same. Huge caramel, nutty character through the middle. Spicy/herbal hops in backend. Creamy/smooth mouthfeel.

Can. Pour is a black-red with a tight frothy head and solid lacing. Aroma is malt coffee and coco. Taste is more malt with faint coffee and coco and burnt malt. Palate is chaulky and finishes dry. This is amazing! I have not had this one since Coffee Bender was released, and I am quite surprised with the similar flavors.
Can. Pours a clear and dark burgundy beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt and caramel. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer.
Brown ale, that smells and tastes more like a pale ale.  Heavy on hop content, medium on the spices, and a little grassy.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is light roasted malt, nutty and a fruity note. Flavour is light roasted malt, light malt acidic and chocolate.

Dressed in brown, he sports gorgeously deep garnet and ruby hues while a soft khaki head floats in suspended animation. A couple swirls and lace decorates the sides of my glass. Holding my glass to the light, he has an old sheen such as one would expect from wood time-tested and worn yet still full of rich beauty and wisdom. His nose is all about molasses and caramel while in the background pine trees flourish and grapefruit tantalizes. I grew up in the citrus industry, surrounded by the wonderful delights of differing grapefruit varietals so for myself at least, grapefruit is a tasty treat indeed. Vanilla bean and licorice mingle well with his sweet side as brown sugars melt under my adoring gaze. For his nose at least, his malty side impresses first before smoothly stepping aside to allow his hops to shine. My first quaff isnt the least bit tentative, and I am met by a creamy mouthfeel which coats the lips and pleases the tongue with fresh molasses and caramel. Im talking natural here, no saccharine artificial sweeteners here; this is the real deal. Weaving in and out of his sweet side are melted brown sugars along with faint esters of vanilla and licorice. Pine needles prickle and grapefruit exudes self-confidence from the middle of his palate all the way through a long finish. Pine resin adds to his sticky mouthfeel while grapefruit sports acidic juices and bitter skins. Furthering our journey down canned beer lane, I detect a quick kiss of cherry tartness in the transition between sweet and hoppy. A few more generous quaffs and both can and glass are empty, a sad occasion one would not guess by the merry smile glued to my face.

16 oz can courtesy of Greg.  Pours a dark yet clear coppery maple wood amber with a creamy medium sized beige head.  Aroma of nuts, oats, cocoa powder and a hint of light coffee.  Taste of faint nuts, cocoa powder, dry tree branches, toffee and cream.
Bottle @ J.C.G US Tasting, Pt 3. Pours dark brown with a creamy head and lacings. Nose is sweet malty. Caramel, bread, toffee, fruit and nuts. Smooth and chewy malt flavor. Nice.

16oz can thanks to Tharreld. pours a brown / red color with a 2 finger frothy brown head.  Very nice aromas coming from this brown ale... layers of sweet malts, light coffee, caramel, hops and oats. Medium body with nice carbonation, coffee, dark fruits, nuts, more caramel malts, oats, and a really nice level of bitterness. Bitter, chocolate, sweet oat finish.  This is one damn good dynamic Brown Ale.

Can from my "Secet" Santa Skyview. Thanks Bob! Pours clear dark brown, thick pillowy head, gorgeous lacing. I honestly cant fathom a brown ale looking better than this. Nose is dark grains, slight spiciness, dark fruits, caramel, a certain "woody" character, so Im guessing English hops. Flavors are multifaceted and rich, toasty caramel, flinty graphite, nice all-over mouthfeel. A tremendously pleasing beer. Im only about a quarter through it now, and Im very much looking forward to the other 3/4 of this one.
Aroma: caramel, bread, chocolate, coffee, nuts. Appearance: brown, tan foam. Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter. Palate: medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, abrupt finish.

Thanks to Tharreld for the can!! It pours brownish red with an orangy/tan head. It has a faintly dusty, toasted aroma with hints of caramel, berries, and brown sugar. The flavor is toasted malt, oatmeal, and some berryish hop astringency. Notes of nuts and cocoa as well. It has a very hoppy, bitter finish. Overall, an above average brown ale.

On tap at Sheffields in Chicago. Pours a deep brown with a small creamy off white head. The aroma has cocoa powder, toasted malts, very nutty sharpness to it, and quite a bit of hoppiness, very fresh and earthy hops. Flavor is even hoppier than originally expected. Starting malty, roasted nuts, caramel, cocoa beans and a little cocoa powder. Then getting a big dose of hops, almost to the point of finishing like a black IPA, really sharp bitterness that blends with all the malts. Medium full body. Pretty good brown ale, though it seems to deviate from the traditional style with the assertive hoppiness.

1 Pint can.  Pours brown-red with a white head.  Nose is malt, nuts, cocoa, and some coffee.  Flavor is similar with malt, nuts, and cocoa powder hanging around.  This brown ale finishes with lingering yeast and cocoa.  Interesting brown ale.

Dark brown liquid that really appears to be a deep magenta when held up to the light. The beige head leaves excellent lacing. Nutty and malty with a slight metallic tinge. I dont know if this some kind of deep-seated subconscious suspicion of canning, but theres a note in there that doesnt quite work perfectly.   There are hops, good clean malt and an appropriate level of nuttiness. There are also subtle notes of chocolate and roast. Good feel.  Easy to drink brown ale.
Pours a dark brown color with a thin tan head. Has a nutty chocolate smell to it. Taste is more or less the same but with a slight bitter after taste. Overall not a bad brown.

16 oz. bomber can......Dark Brown with a black creamy head. Earthy tones in the aroma but not much.   Initially, earthy and orange notes. Chocolate flavor.  Over all it tasted like a light beer that was dark in color.  Decent but nothing to write home about.

can poured a dark ruby brown in color with a one finger light tan head. aroma has nutty brown malt, well integrated hops, and a bit of earthy richness with the oats. mouth feel is medium for the style and the carbonation on the lighter side. I was hoping for a little more thickness from the oats. flavor comes off with loads of malt, generous hops lending bitterness, earth, light bitter cocoa, nuts, and a light lactic finish. Interesting that the most oats are in the flavor. overall a nice take on a brown with nice bold malted flavors.

Draft at Hopleaf. Roast brown with a poofy soft head of foam. Nice nutty aroma. First impression is of creamy goodness -- This drinks on with a really easy-going style for a rowdy brew. Excellent. (#3904, 5/8/2010)

Definitely a different brew - too thin to be a porter but more complex than your typical boring brown ale.  Definitely easy drinking, as Surly describes, but does have light hop notes and variety of malt flavors to make it interesting.  On tap at Hopleaf.

On tap.  Poured a dark brown with dark ruby highlights.  Nice khaki head.  Nutty aroma with a hint of coffee, too.  Flavor is creamy with flavors of nuts, oats, and coffee.  Has a dry and slightly bitter finish.  Very smooth and silky on the palate.  Very nice.

Had this on draft at Jake Melnicks in Chicago. Dark Brown with a black creamy head, nice lacing on the glass. Some earthy tones in the aroma but not much. Initially, earthy and orange notes. Also A little chocolate flavor reminded me of stale brownies. Medium bodied and carbonation, hoppy bitter finish at the end. I had this beer after drinking a glass of the Surly Furious. I couldnt really tell if the hoppiness I was tasting was leftover finish of the Furious, or if it was part of this beer as well, but that taste didnt work well with me in this beer. Hopefully, I can review it again if I come accross it.

A- Body is nearly transparent mahogany hue. Pours with a 1-2 finger off-white foamy head. Head eventually fades to 1/2 finger and has perfect retention from there. Plenty of lacing left all the way down the glass.

S- A bright citrus hoppy scent comes through first. This is followed by roasted chocolate and caramel malt accented with a touch of vanilla and toffee sweetness.

T- The flavor initially has a big citrus hop accent but a nice balance of caramel and chocolate malt can be detected in the background along with a hint of vanilla. For the finish a bit of hop and roasted malt bitterness comes through but is balanced by the ever steady flavors of citrus hops, vanilla, and caramel malt. What lingers is some citrus hop flavor along with a subtle hint of everything else going on.

P- Medium tingly carbonation and a medium weight body. Body is smooth and a good amount of hop oils can be detected.

O- This is an awesome brown ale. One of my favorites so far. Reminds me a lot of Terrapin Indian Brown. Great hoppy characteristics accent a nice, complex brown ale with a good mouthfeel. Would trade for this again; though it is similar to the Terrapin which is locally available. Drinkability is great and ABV is undetectable.

Serving type: can

16 oz. can from dalzale- thanks again, Greg!  Pours a somewhat cloudy brown with a small tan head.  Nice, straightforward aroma: roasted malts, caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, oats, and light coffee notes.  The flavor really pops, though, with roasted malts, toast, nuts, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, and oats.  I had the Coffee Bender a couple months ago, and this is better to me because the coffee notes are turned way down and the others emerge.  Medium-bodied, with average carbonation and a roasty mouthfeel and finish.  Excellent brown ale.

A: The pour is a light brown color with a fingers worth of slightly off-white foam.

S: The nose is sweet and malty with some nice nut, bread, and roasted malt notes.

T: The flavor is quite similar to the nose offering up some toasty, bready malts. There is a nice sweet caramel malt flavor as well, which is nicely balanced by a touch of bitterness on the finish.

M: A medium bodied beer with a pleasant creaminess on the tongue.

D: Another solid beer from Surly. One of the better brown ales Ive had the chance to try as it balances the sweetness and nuttiness quite well.

On tap at Social House in Chicago. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Malty and crisp nose with a bit of roast. Crisp caramel malty flavor up front with notes of fruit and a bitter finish.  Some chocolate taste in there.  Really good and very drinkable.

Out of can into 20oz Irish pub glass. Dark brown color with thin tan head. Roasted caramel aroma. Lacking a bit in body. Taste of sweet caramel and other roasted malts. Palate leaves a coffee taste as well as a bit of aluminum.
Can pours out a brown with some red highs topped with a tan head. Aroma is of sweet caramel malts, and a nice hop presents. Taste is more of the malts a little nut along with some bitter hops kick.

Can, thanks to GrOve for sharing!  Low light brown head. Clear, deep burgundy body. Nutty malt aroma with a sourish, light ashy twist. Notes of yellow fruits, and a hint of cheesy hops. Taste is malt driven, roasted and fairly dry, with a restrained coffee flavor and some mild fruitiness. Very soft on the palate. Mid-bodied. Lasting, roasted and coffe-ish malt finish. Very likeable.

Can shared by gr0ve. Pours a dark ruby red with a creamy tan head. Aroma is of tobacco, caramel, nuts, citrus and metal. Alright. Coffee comes in in the flavour, along with a hard roasted malt finish. Light bodied, with creamy, smooth carbonation. Nice. I did like this, but the finish was a bit too rough.

Can received from Secret Santa Winter 2009 - thanks!  Pours a deep brown with a slightly off-white head.  Nose is a bit restrained, but what is there is a very nice toasty malt, caramel, honey, a bit floral, maybe a little tea.  Flavor is a really great toasted malt, balanced by a somewhat grassy bitterness with just a dusting of cocoa.  Toasted bitter finish.  This is a solid beer.

Can (yay can!) thanks to DuffManSW.  Dark dark brown pour with faint ruby highlights and a 2-finger, frothy, off-white head.  The aroma is creamy and chocolaty with notes of oats, vanilla and earthy resinous pine.  The flavor follows trough from the aroma with the malt adding some toffee and biscuit.  This is definitely well hopped as there is a lasting piny bitterness after you take a swallow blended with a creamy earthiness from the oats.  The body is dry, very smooth and creamy with soft carbonation.

Dark brown with hints of orange and ruby, light brown head. Aroma is generally faint -- hints of some caramel and vanilla notes, pine hops as well. As far as flavor goes, the pine hops dominate -- while not overpowering, they could be balanced by more malty flavors like the coffee and chocolate. Still, the drinkability factor cannot be discounted, and it seems as though the brewers want an easy-drinking beer over a robust beer. Subtle, yes, but the "subtlety" strikes me as more a lack of substance than it is truly subtle. Goes down nice and oily, rather slick, which coats the mouth with a bitterness, and the bitterness becomes too much. A nice start, but some refinements are needed here.

Dark and malty, this ale will make you feel like a true beer connoisseur. Notes of chocolate, caramel, and vanilla remind you of a tasty dessert. I drank this beer for the first time while ice fishing-- the beer sat on slab of snow and ice, chilling ever so slowly after each sip. Makes you feel like you ate a small meal...in a good way.

On tap at Hop Leaf. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Malty and crisp nose with a bit of roast. Crisp malty flavor up front with notes of fruit and a bitter finish. Not bad, but didnt quite live up to the expectations I had for the base beer of Coffee Bender.

Can from j12601-  thanks jay!  pours a dark brown with a nice, big, long lasting, cratery tan head.  Leaves some aesthetically pleasing lacework on the mf glass.  Aroma is toasted malts, aluminum, cream, coffee, and milk chocolate.  The metalic note was much more apparent while the beer was cold and the aroma was, unsurprisingly, much more enjoyable after it calmed.  Flavor is a creamy, coffee, toasted, roasted malt concoction.  pretty nice.  Medium body.  crisp, clean, refreshing.  Good beer- pretty satisfied with the surly canned lineup.  Thanks again Jay.

Pours dark brown with off tan head, aroma is full of coffee and chocolate.  The beginning of the taste is surprisingly (and refreshingly) hoppy that leads into a wonderful chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel blend of sweetness that bitters nicely from the hops at the end.  Excellent and the best brown ale Ive had!

Bottle thanks to brian23456 (BA)!Transparent mahogany with a cream ring for a head. Nose has vanilla, plum, chocolate and light coffee. Flavor is a bit ashy, which creates a singular flavor in chocolate dust, also some minor coffee and nut. Pretty silky body, light bitterness in the finish but no hop balance to enjoy. Drinkable, sweet, and balanced, just lacking some nuance.

Can courtesy of tytoanderso most likely.  Pours a deep clear brown with a medium tan head. Coffee, plum, caramel, and vanilla on the nose.  Medium bodied with coffee, malt, and roast flavors balanced with a touch of sweetness.  Smooth roast and vanilla and plum finish.  Tasty stuff.

Ruby brown, particulate laden and a creamy brown head and some frothy lacing.  Aroma of caramel, vanilla, light coffee, sweet malt, light chocolate and a touch of grains.  Creamy body tastes of coffee, mild hops, roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, oatmeal - reminds me a bit of a tootise roll.  A little citrus in there too.  Perhaps a hair thin and contains a touch of sourness and mild bitterness on the back end.  Someone forgot to mention to this beer that its a brown ale.  Low expectations going in based on style but this was solid.

Bender is a very, very dark brown beer. The head is a coffee-stain color and bumpy around the edges. It smells like chocolate milk as well as oats, mmm. The taste is really, really good but I cant liken it to another flavor. The mouthfeel is very smooth. I dont usually like brown ales but this one is a standout beer. I also really like the 16 ounce cans Surly uses, nice.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 05-24-2007 19:17:04

Can from Tim (Hophead22). Aroma of malts, oats, with a subtle hint of sweetness. Dark brown pour with thick bubbly tan head. Roasted dark malts, light hops, cocoa, cream, oats. Smooth medium frothy carb. Very enjoyable.

16 oz can from Daknole. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of toasted malts and cocoa. Roasted malts, coffee and chcolate flavors with a slightly bitter finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation. A very good brown ale.

RBSG 07. On tap at Surly. Dark brown/amber, ruby hues. Small tan head. Drinks like a bit fuller english brown without a twang. Toasty, biscuity, fresh oats. Creamy on the palate with a little carbonation bite on the finish. Medium body. Solid brown ale. From notes.

16oz Can.   Dark brownish color with big foamy tan head.  Aroma has some hops, nuts and touch of caramel and chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, a touch a biter chocolate, and more nuts.  Very balanced and even better than the Coffee Bender.

can, pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, toffee, and carmel malt.  Delicious bitter sweet malt with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Finishes slightly spicey with notes of clove and pepper.  Really nice sessionable brown ale.
50 cl can, Fargo, ND, USA. Burnt almond and roasted coffee aroma with a spicy . Smooth, creamy, bitter chocolate flavor with a spicy, almost basil-like finish.

Poured from can into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Very dark ruby-brown with an inch thick tan head that very slowly recedes, leaving fine lacing down the glass.

Aroma of sweet caramel, citrus hops, some roasted malts.

Slightly sweet caramel, roasted malts, oats, slight coffee and chocolate, and a very nice citrus hop counterbalance. Finishes on a moderate bitter note.

Low carbonation, rich medium body, dry body. Very smooth for such a low abv beer.

At 5.1% abv, this is the ideal year round session beer in Minnesota. It is also the best Brown Ale (whether English, American, India or hybrid) that I have had.
16 oz can. pours dark brown with a cream head.  niec aromas of carmel, malt, chocolate that mold into a nice beer.  this is a great brown ale.

At a tasting, thanks David, small thick head, dark reddish colour with light brownish taints, aromas of tobacco and hints of grassy hops, flavours of nuts, oats and a touch of fruit and soap, strong hoppy bitterness which fades rather quickly and a light sweetness in the back.  Strange beer.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks David C. Dark amber-brown color with a beige head. Nutty aroma with malt, flowery hops, some tropical fruits and pine needles. Bitter piney flavor with some sweet malt, bread, oatmeal and caramel. A pleasant bitter finish. Medium-bodied.

16 oz. can poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of coca, carmel, light vanilla and light coffee. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a smooth finish. Flavors of carmel, cocoa, light coffee, light toffee and a hint of vanilla with a smooth lingering cocoa finish.

Thanks David for sharing this one, pours deep red with a thick tan head, aroma of grapefruit, pine, lemon, wine and yeast, flavor is mainly bitter, low sweetness, grapefruit peel, medicinic bitterness, complexity is low and does not support the level of bitterness.

Can.  Pours a deep brown body with a tan head.  Roasted malt, caramel, light coco and roast y tones.  Caramel with a light vanilla and a mild bittering finish. Great base for my beloved coffee bender.

Thanks to MatSciGuy.  Pour is deep dark brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is roasted caramel malt, light chocolate, light coffee, earthy, and brown sugar.  Flavor is crisp cookie malt with a a nice balance of sweetness and roasty bitterness.  Notes off coffee and vanilla linger.  Very easy to drink fuller bodied beer.

Can from allendodd. Thanks loads! Pours a very dark brown with a foamy tan head. Aromas of chocolate and treacle. Medium body with frothy carbonation. Flavors of citrus/resin over nicely roasted malt. Treacle too. Very smooth brown ale. But with lots of flavor. Finishes with a nice level of bitter on the rear tongue edges. Good beer.

Sample at Brewnosers meeting April 2008. Brown colour with a mostly lasting frothy off-white head. Chocolate, citrus, coffee, and molasses aroma. Chocolate, bready, earthy, and coffee flavours with a citrus and piny bitter finish, medium bodied, rich, and lightly chewy but refreshing.

Can - Pours mahogany with a nice creamy tan head thats gone pretty quickly. Lots of sweet malt in the nose, giving off caramel, vanilla, raisins, and just a touch of alcohol. Taste isnt quite as good out of the can as I remember on tap. Its sour and milky and finishes with some bitter chocolate, coffee, and hops. A little watery, but with enough body to still feel a little creamy. Not my favorite Surly brew, but still very solid.

Source:500 mL can. 
Glass:Killians English pint. 
Appearance:Clear brown pour (similar to Coke) with a thin off white head.
Aroma:Aroma was nuts and chocolate. 
Flavor:Flavor was caramel malt, with a nutty finish.  A hint of chocolate on the front end as well. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:This was good, but not as good as Moose Drool or other similar beers.
Pretty damn good for what it is, but it seems like these guys dont know how to make a beer without a lot of hops.

16 oz. can - thanks to tytoanderso for the trade; thin, light cola brown with foamy tan head; a little sweet with mild astringency; nutty with touch of chocolate on the nose; not that interesting overall; the coffee addition does wonders to this base
On tap at Hop Leaf. This dark brown ale poured with a thin beige head and a chocolate aroma. There is a sour, but pleasant,  smooth chocolate and roasted malt flavor and a bit of carbonation.

A flavoursome, superior brown ale. I really like the American take on whats often a rather dull style. Lovely caramel flavours with mocha notes and hints of vanilla. Medium bodied and soft in mouthfeel. As with everything we tried from Surly, this is really nice work. (Can courtesy of Oslo - thanks buddy - at the Milson Point park session September 09)

Brown color, with a really nice rudy/umber color when held to the light. Tallish, somewhat creamy, aged canvas hued head. Good lace. Toasted malt, light chocolate, dark caramel, and herbal hops in the aroma. Smells like a brown ale, nothing to exciting for me. Thin toasted malt flavors in the start. Gets more bitter and starts to get tinny and thinner the deeper in I get into it. After having the CB yesterday, I can recall the base, and now can taste how much the coffee added. HInts of fruit in the middle. Finish is dry and bitter. Really quite boring without the coffee.

600ml can, courtesy of Oslo, Ratebeer tasting under the Bridge 12/9.  Quickly fading frothy tan head on a deep brown body.  Mild roasty aroma, maybe some vanilla essence too.  Flavour of caramel and oats. More interesting than the average brown ale.

Draught at Ikes, Minneapolis airport. Dark brown with orange and a fine, tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and chocolate. Flavor of roasted chocolate, caramel, thick malt; fruity too, with a tart touch and a roasty finish, with some bitter hops and a reasonably full mouth. Nice stuff.

16oz can from theisti. Nose is interesting - coffee and hops with a caramel and bready malt backbone. Flavor is also interesting, like no other beer Ive had - intiially toasty chocolate and malted milk ball flavor that soon mingles with the creamy oatmeal and finishes a dry, bitter hop profile. A little strange, but very well executed. Not my thing entirely, but as with all the other Surly brew Ive tried, its very well cared for. Thanks, Tim.

On tap at the hopleaf in Chi city. Wow nice beer
brown color good head some lacing runs down the glass after. smell is hoppy but also almost get brown sugar or something along those lines. mouthfeel is thick and creamy flavor is malty with soe bittering hops to finish.

16oz can thanks to photomike.   Dark brown with a lasting beige head.   The aroma is a nice grain blend with some oats, dark toasted bread, light chocolate malt, dusty cocoa powder and a hint of caramel.   It is subtle, but there is a lot of nuance.   The flavor is light on sweetness but still has a nice toasty, chocolatey and lightly roasty malt component with a medium grapefruit peel bitterness that is mostly in balance with the malt.   Creamy body that is a little on the heavier side, but certainly not thick.   A very good brown ale that I thoroughly enjoyed.   I have to say that I have been nothing but amazed with Surly thus far.

16 oz. can acquired via trade with tennisjoel.  Dark brown pour with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts with light vanilla notes and some floral hops.  Very good full-flavored roasted malt flavor along with some hints of chocolate, smoke, and coffee.  This is probably the best brown ale I have ever had.  Whereas I find most of them to be rather dull this is more of a slightly lighter version of a porter.  Very nicely done.
